text: This is my comfort in my affliction: for thy word hath quickened me.
text_kjv: This is my comfort in my affliction: for thy word hath quickened me.
text_niv: My comfort in my suffering is this:Your promise preserves my life.
text_esv: This is my comfort in my affliction, that your promise gives me life.
text_nlt: Your promise revives me;it comforts me in all my troubles.
text_msg: These words hold me up in bad times;yes, your promises rejuvenate me.
text_nasb: This is my comfort in my affliction, That Your word has revived me.
context: Psalm 119, the longest chapter in the Bible, is an acrostic poem, with each section dedicated to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet. Each of the 22 sections (containing 8 verses each) explores a different facet of God's Word (Torah, law, statutes, precepts, etc.). It's a testament to the profound impact the Law had on the Psalmist's life. Understanding the historical context requires acknowledging the centrality of the Torah in Jewish life. During the time of the Psalmist (likely post-exilic), the Torah served not only as legal code but also as a source of national identity, spiritual guidance, and hope for restoration. Affliction was a common reality, whether from personal struggles, national oppression, or spiritual battles. The word 'quickened' (חָיָתְנִי – chayyatheni) suggests not merely being made alive but restored, invigorated, and given new energy. It goes beyond survival; it implies flourishing even in the midst of hardship. The Psalmist finds solace not in worldly possessions or human comforts but in the very words of God. This showcases a deep trust in the divine promise and power inherent in scripture. The meticulous structure of Psalm 119 underscores the Psalmist's deliberate and comprehensive devotion to God's Word, emphasizing its multifaceted role in his life. The repetitive nature of the themes reinforces their importance within the Jewish religious experience. The author likely belonged to a community where studying and living by the Torah was of paramount importance, thus shaping their understanding of comfort and resilience.
meaning: Psalm 119:50 reveals a profound understanding of the relationship between God's Word and the believer's experience of suffering. 'This is my comfort' establishes the verse as a declaration of personal conviction. The Psalmist isn't simply stating a theological truth but expressing a lived reality. 'In my affliction' acknowledges the presence of hardship and suffering. It's not a denial of pain but a recognition of its existence. The Psalmist doesn't sugarcoat the difficulty but embraces the reality of his circumstances. Crucially, the verse doesn't present affliction as something to be avoided at all costs but as an opportunity for God's comfort to be revealed. 'For thy word hath quickened me' is the core of the verse's meaning. The word 'quickened' implies a dynamic, life-giving power. It speaks to the transformative impact of God's Word. It's not just information; it's an active force that revives, restores, and renews the soul. The Psalmist is asserting that God's Word, specifically, has been the source of his revitalization amid affliction. This quickening refers to both spiritual and emotional restoration. It could encompass forgiveness, guidance, hope, or a renewed sense of purpose. The phrase 'thy word' emphasizes the personal relationship between the Psalmist and God. It's not just any word, but God's specific word, revealed and applied to his particular situation. This implies an active engagement with scripture, seeking God's specific guidance and comfort within its pages. The verse highlights the power of God's Word to transcend temporal circumstances and offer lasting hope and resilience.
application: Psalm 119:50 offers a powerful message for modern believers facing various challenges. In a world filled with anxieties, uncertainties, and suffering, it reminds us that true and lasting comfort is found not in fleeting pleasures or worldly possessions but in God's Word. The verse challenges us to actively engage with scripture, not merely as a religious duty, but as a source of life-giving power. It prompts us to ask: How can we cultivate a deeper connection with God's Word in our daily lives? This could involve setting aside dedicated time for Bible reading and reflection, joining a Bible study group, or memorizing scripture verses that resonate with our personal struggles. When facing affliction, the verse encourages us to turn to God's Word for solace and guidance. Instead of succumbing to despair or seeking comfort in unhealthy coping mechanisms, we can find renewed strength and hope by meditating on scripture and praying for God's wisdom. Consider journaling about your struggles and then seeking relevant scriptures that offer insight and encouragement. The Psalmist's experience reminds us that God's Word is not a static text but a living, active force that can transform our hearts and minds. This requires a willingness to be open to the Holy Spirit's guidance as we read and study scripture. Practice Lectio Divina – a method of slowly reading scripture, meditating on its meaning, praying about it, and contemplating its application to your life. Further, apply this verse by sharing your experiences with others, offering encouragement and pointing them to the Word of God as a source of comfort during their own trials. Remember that God's Word has the power to quicken not only our own lives but also the lives of those around us.
prayer: Heavenly Father, in moments of suffering and despair, remind me to turn to Your Word as my ultimate source of comfort. I confess that I often seek solace in temporary things that fail to satisfy. Forgive me for neglecting the life-giving power of scripture. Grant me a hunger for Your Word, that I may find renewed strength, guidance, and hope within its pages. Help me to meditate on Your promises and to trust in Your unwavering love, even in the midst of my afflictions. Let Your Word quicken my spirit, restore my soul, and empower me to overcome every challenge. Thank you for providing such a powerful and accessible source of comfort. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To quicken means more than just to make alive. It means to invigorate, restore, and give new energy. In the context of Psalm 119:50, it implies that God's Word has the power to revive the Psalmist's spirit during times of affliction, providing hope and strength to persevere.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean for God's Word to 'quicken' someone?

faqs.answer: Start by praying for guidance and wisdom. Then, actively seek scriptures that address your specific situation. Explore relevant themes like hope, healing, forgiveness, or peace. Use a concordance or online resources to search for verses related to your struggle and meditate on their meaning.
faqs.question: Q2: How can I find specific comfort in God's Word when I'm suffering?

faqs.answer: The verse doesn't necessarily imply that affliction is good in itself, but rather that it can be an opportunity to experience God's comfort in a deeper way. Affliction can drive us to seek God's Word, where we find solace, guidance, and renewed strength.
faqs.question: Q3: Is this verse suggesting that affliction is good because it leads us to God's Word?

faqs.answer: Write the verse on a note card and carry it with you. Repeat it aloud throughout the day. Break the verse into smaller phrases and memorize each phrase individually. Associate the verse with a specific image or emotion. Review memorized verses regularly to reinforce them.

faqs.answer: Psalm 119 is an extensive meditation on the value of God's Word. Verse 50 exemplifies the overarching theme of the psalm, demonstrating how God's Word provides guidance, comfort, and hope in all circumstances, highlighting its central role in the believer's life.
